title: Figma Unveils AI-Powered Erase, Isolate, and Expand Tools for Seamless In-Canvas Image Editing

paragraphs.content: Figma launched three new AI image-editing tools—Erase object, Isolate object, and Expand image—on December 10, 2025, bundling them into a contextual toolbar for precise edits directly on the canvas. These features enable designers to remove unwanted elements, extract and reposition subjects while preserving lighting and texture, and extend image edges for new aspect ratios without distortion. The tools join existing capabilities like Remove background and Crop, reducing the need to export to Photoshop or Canva for routine fixes.

paragraphs.content: The upgraded lasso selection ensures surrounding colors, lighting, and textures remain stable post-edit, avoiding common AI artifacts. Figma targets everyday frustrations in UI and marketing workflows, such as adapting hero images for banners or social assets. Independent demos showcase the toolbar's one-click access to annotations, color tweaks, and background removal, streamlining multi-format design tasks.

sections.title: Breakdown of Erase, Isolate, and Expand Capabilities

paragraphs.content: Erase object lets users lasso and remove specific items from raster images, with AI filling the space naturally by matching adjacent colors and textures. Isolate object extracts selected subjects for repositioning or property adjustments like shadow, focus, or color, keeping the background consistent. Figma's blog highlights use cases like brightening product shots or desaturating distractions to emphasize key elements.

paragraphs.content: Expand image fills extended borders to reshape compositions, such as turning square photos into wide web headers without cropping or distortion. The new toolbar centralizes these with prior tools, prioritizing frequent actions like background removal based on user data. Release notes confirm availability in Figma Design and Draw for eligible plans.

sections.title: Hands-On Performance and Early Tester Feedback

paragraphs.content: YouTube demos reveal strong results for routine assets like thumbnails and banners, with the lasso tool praised for precision in object handling. Reviewers note natural fills in Erase and Isolate but occasional artifacts on complex edges or textures during stress tests. Tech coverage emphasizes workflow gains, calling the tools practical upgrades over prompt-based generation.

Figma plans broader rollout across products in 2026, gated now to Professional, Organization, and Enterprise full seats with AI enabled. Community tests advise using these for quick UI fixes while reserving Photoshop for pixel-level retouching. The launch aligns with industry trends, as Adobe integrates similar features into ChatGPT the same day.
